tempoAndCardAdvantage.description: Tempo describes how efficiently you're using resources vs opponent. Card advantage measures cards in hand relative to opponent.
keyPoints: Early deployment: Summon low-cost characters that challenge effectively
Removal timing: Use removal before opponent's synergy triggers
Quest/Challenge balance: Know when to exert for lore vs staying ready
Combining tempo + card advantage is lethal - control the flow of the game
tempoAndCardAdvantage.tempoDecks: Feature 2-3 cost creatures with immediate board impact, snowball advantage by having more creatures than opponent

inkCurve.description: Balanced distribution of cards across different costs for playable options at every stage
inkCurve.warning: Don't get stuck with high-cost uninkable cards - consider 40-50% of deck should be ink-eligible

keywordSynergy.evasive: Can only be challenged by other Evasive characters. Deck built around Evasive forces opponent to run Evasive or use removal
keywordSynergy.bodyguard: Can redirect challenges, protecting key questers. Don't waste them as ink
keywordSynergy.shift: Play upgraded versions at reduced cost if base version exists. Accelerates tempo significantly
keywordSynergy.importance: Don't neglect staple effects just to jam more synergy

steps: Identify common decks in your area/online
Reserve 2-3 flex slots for meta tech cards
If sideboarding allowed, treat as targeted solution kit

mulliganStrategy.goal: Assemble an ink curve with 1-drop on turn 1, 2-drop on turn 2, etc
mulliganStrategy.aggressive: Mulligan duplicate ink costs, keeping best of each drop
examples: Two 1-drops, three 3-drops = keep one 1-drop and one 3-drop, bottom rest to find 2-drop and 4-drop
Perfect 1-2-3-4 curve + 4 different 4-drops = keep good 4-drop, bottom others to find 5-6 drop
mulliganStrategy.warning: Be careful with non-inkable cards - bottom some if hand has more than 2. Avoid aggressive mulligans if deck has 25%+ non-inkable

inkellingDecisions.goal: Plan ahead, mapping first few turns to ensure smooth curve
principles: Turn 1-5: Always ink something to curve out properly
Ink the worst card you won't play if something better is available
If hand is worst 4-drop, best 5-drop, two 2-drops: ink worst 4-drop and keep excess 2-drop
Late game: Stop inking after turn 5-6 if you've hit natural mana cap (e.g., 5 ink spent/turn)

questingVsChallenging.principle: Only quest when ahead and/or safe. Game is about maintaining board state that gains 20 lore faster.
rules: If opponent is ahead in race: challenge defensively
If board is equal: don't quest if it gives favorable trade
Board control is more important than rushing lore early game
Challenge is control strategy, questing is aggro strategy

cardValuation.note: Willpower appears more important than strength or lore values

whoIsTheBeatdown.description: Fundamental question: Am I trying to finish fast (beatdown) or stabilize and grind (control)?
whoIsTheBeatdown.beatdown: Player trying to push to win as fast as possible. Quest aggressively. Finish before opponent's finishers matter.
whoIsTheBeatdown.control: Player stabilizing and stopping opponent. Challenge and remove threats. Buy time for your answers.
whoIsTheBeatdown.fluid: In Lorcana the question changes turn by turn based on board state and hand strength
whoIsTheBeatdown.decisionRule: When tempted to quest for lore: Am I the beatdown? If no, prioritize stabilizing over questing

tempoPlays.definition: Plays that build momentum or disrupt opponent's progress while advancing your own
tempoPlays.example: Bounce high-cost threat back to hand instead of removing. Costs them another turn, gives you time to draw answer
tempoPlays.value: Buying one turn of unopposed questing (if you're beatdown) is regularly enough to win games
tempoPlays.principle: Lorcana is game of small incremental advantages that add up to 20 lore

stayOnCurve.definition: Every turn drop card into inkwell and play card using that ink. 1-drop T1, 2-drop T2, etc
stayOnCurve.mistake: Playing inkable 1-costs on turn 2 just because you have ink available
stayOnCurve.priority: Ensure you can drop that amazing 6-8 cost card on turn 6-8 when you hit it
stayOnCurve.overInking: Don't keep going past natural mana cap. Most decks lack drawing power. Holding cards lets you play around removal

playAroundRemoval.ruby: Be aware of: Be Prepared (board wipe at 7 ink), Dragon Fire (4 copies likely)
playAroundRemoval.steel: Be aware of: Grab Your Sword, Smash, Fire the Cannons (assume 3-4 copies if seen)
tactics: Don't throw down weak characters to get exiled
Play smaller threat first to bait removal before deploying your big threat
Keep characters in hand to replace removed ones
Don't overcommit to board vs Ruby/Steel

tradeUp.definition: Exchange a card for opponent's card of higher value (usually by ink cost)
tradeUp.good: Your 1-cost takes out their 2-cost - you're ahead
tradeUp.bad: Your 4-cost trades with their 3-cost - net negative
tradeUp.principle: Equal trades only work if you're ahead. Always trade upwards in value

patience.principle: Lorcana is won by building and maintaining board state that reaches 20 lore, not racing
patience.timing: Only throw everything on board when opponent is 15+ lore AND board shows you'll lose in 2 turns
rules: Only quest aggressively if you're beatdown
Play ink and cards on curve
Don't get baited into board wipes
Trade to remove higher value opponent cards

rubyAmethystAggroControl.idea: Ruby aggressive minions + Amethyst draw and Shift for sustained pressure
cards: Low-cost Ruby characters with 2 lore icons for quick questing
Amethyst Shift characters that upgrade cheaply to outscale
Removal songs/actions that double as ink if ahead or removal if behind
decisions: When to quest aggressively vs save for challenges
Timing Shift upgrades without losing tempo
Balancing uninkable vs inkable card ratio

emeraldSapphireMidrangeControl.idea: Sturdy Sapphire characters for stalling, mid-cost Emerald units that debuff and control

curve.early: 1-2 cost defensive minions or item draw
curve.mid: 3-5 cost creatures that remove or hamper threats
curve.late: 6-7 cost bombs that flip board or collect lore

strengths: Grinding out value-based decks by outlasting
Surviving hyper-aggro with midrange taunts and removal
Playing defense until big finishers online

princessSynergy.idea: Leverage synergy cards that buff Princess characters specifically
considerations: Enough synergy cards for consistent triggers (don't spread too thin)
Deck functions if key synergy pieces are banished

aggro.goal: Win by turn 5-6 with early pressure
aggro.mulligan: Aggressively mulligan for low-cost openers, accept weak late game
aggro.strategy: Snowball advantage with efficient creatures, force opponent into defensive plays
aggro.curveAdjustment: If avg cost >4, replace 5-8 high-cost cards with low-cost units (1-3)
questions: Do I have enough 1-3 cost creatures for early pressure?
Can I threaten lethal by turn 6?
Do I have evasive creatures to force unfavorable blocks?

control.goal: Survive until turn 7+, win with locked board
control.mulligan: Search for removal and card draw, accept weak early game
control.strategy: Answer every threat, stabilize board, deploy finishers once safe
control.curveAdjustment: If avg cost <4, add 4-6 high-cost cards (5+) as finishers
questions: Do I have enough removal for major threats?
Do I have card draw to maintain tempo?
Can I stabilize before opponent's threats dominate?

midrange.goal: Tempo and value, win with efficient threats into turn 7
midrange.mulligan: Balance of threats and answers, aim for perfect curve
midrange.strategy: Value trades, efficient board presence, flexible answers
midrange.curveAdjustment: If avg cost 4-4.5 (ideal), keep curve. <4: add mid-costers. >4.5: add low-costers
questions: Do I have 50% threats and 50% answers?
Is my deck consistent turn to turn?

starterDeckAdvice.recommended: High-cost inkable characters are like MTG's land/bomb split cards - Lorcana allows top-heavy curves
starterDeckAdvice.upgrade: Remove low-impact items/actions, add more 5-7 cost characters

early_game_priorities: Play to ink curve (T1-T5 add ink each turn)
late_game_priorities: Protect your lore total (20 is finish line)
Have outs if opponent has threats

critical_decision_moments.do_I_quest_or_challenge: Ask: Am I the beatdown? If yes, quest. If no, challenge.
critical_decision_moments.which_cards_to_ink: Ink worst cards you won't play. Plan first 5-6 turns ahead.
critical_decision_moments.when_to_hold_removal: Keep removal for game-ending threats, not low-impact creatures.
critical_decision_moments.how_many_creatures: Minimum 1-2 creatures per turn early, 3+ mid-game, control board late.
critical_decision_moments.when_do_i_pass: Only pass when board is safe or you're out of playable cards.

tempo_aggro.draw: 1-2 card draw effects (optional, tempo is more important)

midrange.goal: Win turns 6-7 with efficient threats + answers

common_mistakes_to_avoid: Playing ink candidates early when you should save them
Questing when you should challenge (behind in tempo)
Overcommitting creatures to board with removal coming
Not counting opponent's lore (always know the race)
Forgetting to ask: Who is the beatdown?
Mulliganing too conservatively for perfect curve
Inking cards you might need later (plan ahead!)
Not playing around known removal threats

overrated: Cards that only work in specific situations
Cards that can't be inked (except essential)
underrated: Evasive creatures (force removal or favorable blocks)

vs_aggro.tactics: Challenge everything, remove threats immediately, life gain if available
vs_aggro.win_condition: Out-value their threats with efficient removal + stabilization

vs_midrange.tactics: Trade up (your 1-drop for their 2-drop), keep hand full, pressure lore
vs_midrange.win_condition: Accumulate small advantages into large leads

vs_control.tactics: Hold cards in hand, bait removal with small threats, deploy finishers when answers are gone
vs_control.win_condition: Have 1-2 finishers when they're out of removal

resource_management.ink_management: Plan first 6 turns of inking. Don't over-ink past natural mana cap. Reserve ink for curve plays.
resource_management.hand_management: Hold cards to play around removal. Don't empty hand on single turn unless you're beatdown.
resource_management.threat_management: Identify 2-3 key threats per turn. Know what you can remove. Know what threatens you.

game_theory.information_advantage: Watch opponent's hand size. Count their discard. Predict their plays.
game_theory.decision_trees: Each action has pros/cons. Consider opponent's responses. Play defensively if unsure.
game_theory.positioning: Order of play matters. Play threats after removal bait. Chain advantages.

tournament_preparation.meta_awareness: Research top decks in your area. Know their gameplans. Build counters.
tournament_preparation.sideboarding: If allowed, prepare answers to meta decks. 8-15 flex cards.
tournament_preparation.mental_game: Stay calm. Play at consistent pace. Don't tilt after losses.

rapid_improvement.playtesting: Play 20+ games with your deck before tournament
rapid_improvement.notes: Write down what beat you and why. Adjust accordingly.
rapid_improvement.watching_vods: Study pro players' decision-making. Learn from their mistakes.
rapid_improvement.deck_refinement: Cut cards that never help. Add cards you desperately needed.

meta_predictions.watch_for: If one deck wins multiple events, expect it everywhere
meta_predictions.build_counters: If Evasive is dominant, add cheap removal or Evasive of your own
meta_predictions.stay_flexible: Keep 2-3 flex slots for last-minute tech cards

rubyAmethyst.description: Aggressive opening with Rush abilities combined with hand manipulation and control. Currently the most consistent tournament performer.
strengths: Turn 1-3 tempo pressure via Rush creatures
Hand disruption (Amethyst) slows opponent setup
Shift mechanics enable mid-game transitions
Can pivot to control with Amethyst spells
Evasive creatures dodge removal
weaknesses: Vulnerable to early board wipes and Resist abilities
Hand manipulation can be disrupted by card draw engines
Falls behind to value-based decks in long games
howToCounter: Pack Steel-based defensive structures with Resist
Use Amber recovery effects to stabilize after hand pressure
Build in early blockers to slow Rush pressure
Include Sapphire draw to rebuild after hand disruption
Run creature-based removal that trades well with early threats

sapphireSteel.description: Resource management and card draw engine paired with powerful defensive characters. Consistent top finisher in regional events.
strengths: Superior card draw and ink smoothing via Sapphire
Steel provides powerful high-willpower creatures with Resist
Can stabilize board quickly with defensive creatures
Answers library enables tech flexibility
Outvalues opponents in long games
weaknesses: Can be outpaced by faster aggro in early game
Sometimes mana-flooded in control mirror matchups
Slow to establish board presence turn 1-2
howToCounter: Build consistent early pressure with Ruby/Amethyst tempo
Deploy threats faster than they can establish answers
Use hand disruption (Amethyst) to prevent drawing key answers
Include creatures with Evasive to bypass Steel blockers
Push damage before they stabilize with draw engine

emeraldSapphire.description: Gameplay manipulation and control effects paired with resource generation. Flexible adaptation to metagame shifts.
strengths: Emerald manipulation answers almost any threat
Sapphire provides resource smoothing and draw
Efficient mid-cost creatures with abilities
Can control game while building board presence
weaknesses: Relies on having answers in hand (vulnerable to resource denial)
Can struggle against consistent threats that snowball
Slower setup than pure aggro decks
howToCounter: Deploy multiple threats simultaneously to overwhelm answers
Use hand pressure (Amethyst discard) to deny answers
Build aggressive curve that applies pressure before they answer
Include creatures with Rush to punch through before blockers
Use Amber recovery to stabilize if they DO answer your threats

amberSteel.description: Early defense and resource recovery paired with late-game power plays. Specifically counters aggressive strategies.
strengths: Early defensive creatures with Resist abilities
Amber recovery mechanics stabilize quickly
Steel provides powerful creatures as ramp payoff
Can execute powerful threats once stabilized
weaknesses: Slower setup allows aggressive decks to build momentum
Recovery mechanics can create card disadvantage situations
howToCounter: Prevent stabilization with consistent early pressure
Use hand disruption to prevent recovery setup
Deploy multiple threats so they can't trade efficiently
Use Sapphire tempo threats to apply pressure faster
Include evasion so they can't block everything

ruby.description: Rush and Evasive abilities enable early pressure
ruby.metaPosition: Staple in aggro and tempo decks. Strong against control.
ruby.currentTrend: Rising in popularity post-Fabled, especially in Ruby/Steel variants

sapphire.description: Ink management and resource generation enable consistent play
sapphire.metaPosition: Essential for control decks. Strong in midrange.
sapphire.currentTrend: Dominant in Sapphire/Steel control, which is tier-1

emerald.metaPosition: Strong in midrange. Versatile in hybrid decks.

steel.metaPosition: Increasingly important in control and tempo-control decks
steel.currentTrend: Rising popularity in Sapphire/Steel and Ruby/Steel

amber.metaPosition: Strong in defensive decks. Emerging in tempo-control.
amber.currentTrend: Solid performer in Amber/Steel defensive decks

amethyst.metaPosition: Staple in aggro-control. Critical for hand denial.
amethyst.currentTrend: Essential in Ruby/Amethyst, highest performer currently

against_rubyAmethyst: Resist creatures - Steel blockers don't take damage from Rush
Early board wipes - prevent snowballing in turns 1-3
Healing/Recovery - Amber effects stabilize before they finish
Card draw engines - rebuild after hand disruption
Creatures with evasion blockers - trade efficiently
against_sapphireSteel: Turn 1-2 pressure - force answers before draw engine
Hand disruption - prevent them from drawing key answers
Multiple simultaneous threats - overwhelm removal suite
Evasive creatures - bypass their Steel blockers
Fast clock - win before they stabilize board
against_emeraldSapphire: Redundant threats - they can't answer everything
Resource denial - discard their answers before turn plays
Cheap efficient creatures - establish presence while they setup
Removal immune creatures - forces their answers to be inefficient
Tempo pressure - apply damage faster than they can stabilize
against_amberSteel: Aggressive early turns - don't let them stabilize
Consistent clock - pressure before finisher turns online

winterspell_february2026.impact: New character pool with Pixar set integration. Meta still stabilizing.
winterspell_february2026.keyCards: New Pixar characters being explored for builds. Evaluate for your archetype.
winterspell_february2026.advice: Test against Winterspell decks. Identify emerging strategies early.

whispers_november2025.impact: Boost mechanic enabled value/snowball strategies. Extended some game lengths.
whispers_november2025.innovation: Boost-focused decks emerged but haven't dominated meta
whispers_november2025.advice: Consider Boost mechanics in matchup analysis. Some decks snowball harder with Boost.

fabled_september2025.impact: Epic and Iconic rarities printed - highest power ceiling ever
fabled_september2025.keyCards: Goofy Movie characters. Epic/Iconic cards from all inks.
fabled_september2025.advice: If you haven't seen Fabled cards in meta yet, expect them to emerge in counters

archazia_march2025.impact: Dual-ink cards introduced - expanded deck flexibility
archazia_march2025.innovation: Dual-ink cards not inherently more powerful, but enabled new builds
archazia_march2025.advice: Dual-ink cards provide flexibility without breaking existing color balance

metaShiftWarnings: Ruby/Amethyst is HIGHEST threat - build specific counters if you see multiple at events
Sapphire/Steel on the rise - if you lose to control, pack tempo pressure
Dual-ink cards (from Archazia) enabled more flexibility - expect less color-predictability
Resist abilities are extremely strong against aggressive decks right now
Shift mechanics are enabling smoother mana in meta decks - don't ignore Shift synergy

against_currentMeta: 1x Cheap removal for Ruby Rush creatures (combat damage prevention)
1x Card draw engine piece (counter hand disruption from Amethyst)
1x Creature with Resist (defensive against aggro pressure)
1x Board wipe or mass answer (prevent snowballing)
1x Hand disruption piece (if not already in deck, pressure their setup)
sideboard_if_available: 2-3 Resist creatures - transforms matchups vs Ruby/Amethyst
2x Early removal suite - flexes for aggro-heavy metagame
2x Card draw pieces - tech in vs hand disruption heavy meta
2-3 Specific archetype counters - adjust to your local meta

tieringGuide.tier_s: Ruby/Amethyst Aggro-Control - Most consistent winner. Play it or counter it.
tieringGuide.tier_1a: Sapphire/Steel Control - Rising popularity. Strong matchup-based deck.
tieringGuide.tier_1b: Emerald/Sapphire Midrange - Flexible. Adapts to metagame.
tieringGuide.tier_2: Amber/Steel Defensive Ramp, Ruby/Steel Tempo - Solid performers with good matchups
tieringGuide.tier_3: Rogue strategies, Mono-color decks - Can steal games but less consistent
tieringGuide.advice: Tier placement changes based on local metagame. Play what you understand.
